programmes.show_description: Celebrating Chopin's birthday and Polish musical culture. Penny Gore presents.
Mark Forrest presents Radio 3's Breakfast show. To get in touch, email 3breakfast@bbc.co.uk.
Join Sarah Walker for a colourful Sunday mix, from Swedish folk celebrations to Spanish-inspired orchestral brilliance and music that hints at the first signs of spring.
Michael Berkeley's guest is Peter Hamlyn, the founder and president of the Brain and Spine Foundation, after working as a neurosurgeon for 40 years.
Sara Mohr-Pietsch collects the musical gems that connect to the overture La Gazza Ladra, including Handel's thundering drums and The Unthanks' folkloric magpie.
From the University of Exeter Mary Harris Memorial Chapel, with music by Malcolm, PÃ¤rt, Lukaszewski and Bach.
Join Alyn for a musical journey across the globe featuring artists from Ethiopia, Japan, America, the UK and more.
Hannah French visits St Paul's Cathedral in London to explore the legacy of composer John Blow, who became master of the choristers at the newly consecrated cathedral in 1687.
Fictional robots and poetic automata alongside music created by and played by machines. With readings from Annette Badland and Daniel Millar.
The comedian, actor and keen amateur musician Nick Mohammed reports on the first British encounters with the music of Hungarian Bela Bartok and how our attitudes changed over time.
The Building a Library recommended recording from yesterday's Record Review.
Kate Molleson and Gillian Moore shine new light on the 'modern' music of the 20th century. This week, Gillian explores the music of the Dutch radical Louis Andriessen.
A service of night prayer from the Church of Our Most Holy Redeemer, Clerkenwell, London. With words and music for the end of the day, including works by Otero and Willan.
Hannah Peel presents an adventurous, immersive soundtrack for late-night listening, from classical to contemporary and everything in between.
Elizabeth Alker with a late-night journey through new music from today's most exciting genre-defying artists. Including tracks by Colin Stetson, Michiko Ogawa and Rakel.
The young ensemble performs string quartets by Haydn, Kui Dong and Schumann in this concert from Barcelona. The programme includes Haydn's famously humorous quartet 'The Joke.'.
Linton Stephens presents Radio 3's Breakfast show. To get in touch, email 3breakfast@bbc.co.uk.
Georgia Mann plays the best in classical music, with discoveries and surprises rubbing shoulders with familiar favourites.
Music by Britten and Bridge performed live by one of Radio 3's New Generation Artists, and also this week, exclusive concert recordings of distinctive settings of the church mass.
1/5. Kate Molleson charts the influences upon the early symphonies of Sibelius, including the romantic symphonic music of Tchaikovsky, and themes of Nationalism.
Petroc Trelawny welcomes conductor Mark Elder and composer and pianist Huw Watkins, and there's live music in the studio from recorder ensemble Palisander.
Take time out with a 30-minute soundscape of classical music.
Nicola Benedetti joins the SCO and Principal Conductor Maxim Emelyanychev to perform Brahms and Mendelssohn.

programmes.show_name: The Essay: You, Me and the Wireless
programmes.show_description: Legendary broadcaster Gillian Reynolds shares her life and career in radio, spanning over 50 years.
Hannah Peel presents an adventurous, immersive soundtrack for late-night listening, from classical to contemporary and everything in between.
Soweto's Flowers guest this week, Chilean-born saxophonist Melissa Aldana, shares some of the jazz artists that she has been influenced by.
